comments.commentBody: Ms. Clinton can help those of us on the side of the 99% by assuming the well earned role of elder statesperson. Her candidacy would be very divisive as she is essentially a centrist and would solicit campaign funding from some of the same sources as the Republicans. The "what about Bill" question should be enough for true liberals.

"Hard Choices" -- the title of her forthcoming memoir -- should also be our first clue about what a Clinton third term forebodes. Because "hard choices" is also the common euphemism employed by the plutocratic deficit hawks from both parties to describe the planned gutting of FDR's New Deal and other social programs. As in, "you common folk have to make the hard choice to trim Social Security benefits so as not to rob future generations, while we oligarchs make the hard choice of reaping all the benefits."

Hillary, judging from the age of her recently deceased mother and her gold-plated health insurance, should live long and prosper.

Meanwhile, something she said recently should have us asking the tough questions about the hard choices:

"The 1990s taught us that even in the face of difficult, long-term economic trends, it is possible, through smart policies and sound investments, to enjoy broad-based growth and shared prosperity"

Long on platitudes, short on substance. Nothing, for instance, on taxing the rich or reining in the too big to fail/jail banks. The 90s brought us the end of direct aid to the poor and the reckless repeal of Glass-Steagall, which led directly to financial catastrophe, mass foreclosures and unemployment. The so-called Clinton boom years were a bubble.

Hillary has obstacles from her past, all right. They're named Rubin, Greenspan, Summers, and NAFTA.

Her present obstacles include Warren, Sanders, and the lingering power of the Occupy movement.

"Gather small groups of the great and the good together to hammer out bipartisan reforms." That is what democracy used to look like. Now, however, we have a political party that considers bipartisanship to be treason. A party whose only agenda is to bring down a duly elected President because he belongs to the opposing party. A party that wont even except scientific fact so that there can be an agreed upon basis for bipartisan reform. A party that has no interest in moving forward if it means compromise of any sort. A party that has no respect for the great and little interest in the good anymore. Democracy hasn't failed. It was sabotaged.

Never mind Elite Commissions and Guardian States. Just bring back democracy where elected officials do the right thing for their constituents and for their country, not for the powers that supply the money that gets them elected and expect payback in return.
How would Senators then be elected? or would they be appointed -- and by whom?

Brooks is right - there's too much democracy at the top and not enough at the bottom. A good first step would be to repeal the 17th Amendment, which provided for direct election of U.S. Senators. The Senate was meant to be a collegial, deliberative body, but in the era of Fox News and MSNBC it's just become another House of Representatives.

The other day, there was a piece on "Who gets to graduate?". The subject, Vanessa Brewer, is a young black woman who was doing poorly in college in Texas -- she went to inferior schools, got inflated A grades and did badly on her ACTs.

In Europe, Vanessa would not be able to go to college AT ALL. Sure college is subsidized (not free) in Europe, but then, they do not pretend to try to educate all kids. Only a few kids who excel at tests get to go to European colleges. There are no places for "average" kids let alone weak students like Vanessa -- she would have been shunted into a vocational program.

It's fine to argue for "free" college, but you have to find some way to pay for it. The plan can't just be "soak the rich" -- you need to specifically articulate what taxes and how much will go to give every US student a completely free college education. And oh yeah -- free health care, free day care, a $15 minimum wage, and so on. Please, tell us how much this will cost us all in taxes.

David, you talk about 'western democracies.' But the US differs from most other advanced countries, matter what continent, in important ways that affect all our lives.

Most important, we have privately paid for elections where big money buys the biggest megaphone, thus determines our choice of candidates, and the party platforms.

Most modern democracies avoid the most blatant legalized corruption with publicly paid for elections, giving free TV times for all parties. This makes a huge difference in whose interests are competed for by the candidates. Their elections are hundreds of millions of $ cheaper than ours. And much shorter.

That's why they've had good lower cost national health care for generations already, while we are still fighting that battle. And their college grads graduate with no or little debt--including medical school. While Americans piled up decades of medical bankruptcies and early deaths due to soaring costs and lack of treatment.

Now, college tuition debt is like a big block of cement tied to the feet of our grads, as they try to grab a foothold on adulthood.

Brooks, check out some OECD comparison numbers for the US vs other countries on income inequality and mobility.

Obama stated the other day that 18 other nations rank higher than us in the condition of their transportation and infrastructure. Did that interest you?

It's easy to find this out....just type it into the search box and press Enter. See what you can find.
Hasn't the government been bought and captured by the elite liberal establishment that owns Washington, D.C.? We are no longer red versus blue, but Central Planning against the rest of the country.

Has it occurred to Mr. Brooks that people don't trust our government to do the right thing because our government is no longer responsive to the needs and desires of the people or to the common good? The government has been bought and captured by the rich and they intend to keep it.

This is a sillier than believing they would vote for healthcare reform. I haven't read the book, but from what I've read about it and know of Geithner, he was and still is a global finances, banking and economics wonk, probably not a good lobbyist right after his appointment.

Morally bankrupt Senate Republicans are the real issue. Which Republican's would have been swayed by the wonkish Geithner or one term Senator, and less than two month President Obama lobbying against the newly consolidated financial services industry? Would all 12 Democrats and one Republican, Arlen Spector, who was literally a Democrat in name only because he was Tea Partied just say, "yes sir, I see the light."

Although Treasury and the Obama administration made mistakes people are making a huge one now to cast too much blame on individuals that were at the time fighting for desperately needed stimulus and control of the entire economy that was on its knees.

It has its effect on the victims, for sure, but it doesn't do anything good for the perpetrators either.

And if Judge Dow is going to invoke the Nuremberg defense, then she too should do so under oath.  But that's just an aside. The real question is whether one can have a class of laborers without a class of owners who live off the products of other peoples labor. The answer to that question is decidedly yes. But the answer to the question of whether you can have the owners without the laborers who produce the wealth they own is clearly no.

Labor produces all wealth. In this society wealth is produced socially through cooperative human activity, but the surplus produced (that is to say the wealth produced over and above the costs of reproducing all of the original inputs) is accumulated privately.

It does not have to be so. Those who grow rich off of other peoples labor simply because they have title to wealth produced by previous generations of other peoples labor are parasites.

NYU is one greedy institution. My wife was an adjunct there for 6 years, working roughly 20 hours a week on in and out of class assignments. Her pay for the semester was around $6,000 -- before taxes! And this was one of the department's most important, difficult classes. Not one full-time professor, either with tenure or on the tenure track, was willing to do the scut work of teaching this class. Meanwhile, they taught one or two classes per semester and earned $60,000+. Her situation was very much like that of these workers.  We finally decided enough is enough and she quit. Thanks John Sexton for turning NYU into a money-grubbing farce.

Please - with how hard Sexton, et al., at NYU have fought against graduate students' unionizing so we could get better pay and benefits as adjunct professors?  He can't pretend for a minute that he has any moral obligation to pay a living wage.  In an email from Sexton to NYU community about the wages paid to Abu Dhabi workers:  "wages (those on NYU’s project are paid wages that place them squarely atop the market) and benefits (including healthcare)."  Right.  He doesn't pay that here...why would he ensure it there?

I wish it mattered what the students/grad students did.  Sexton don't care.  He and NYU are making lots of money from this venture, so it doesn't matter what we do.  They'll just keep our tuition money and laugh all the way to the bank.  They would treat their graduate student employees the same if the labor laws in the US allowed for it...but Sexton secured an $800,000/year pension for himself before his retirement.  He likes to pretend it's not on the backs of students and poor construction workers in foreign lands.

" At the national level, American politics has become neurotically democratic."  This is a statement not connected to any experience I have had with respect to current American politics. "Speed at the top", "speed at the bottom" what does it all mean?  Not much, I think. After reading these columns for too long now, I finally realize that whatever Mr Brooks is for, I'm against, so maybe reading this stuff has devolved into pointlessness.

The obscene concentration of wealth that has taken place in the last 40 years is destructive for reasons far beyond the static splitting the pie argument.

One thing that should be clear to all is the way in which the power that derives from over-concentrated wealth is consistently used to further twist the terms of trade in favor of wealthy elites. The agenda of House Republicans, the rulings of the Supreme Court, and the actions of gerrymandered radical-right legislatures are reported, seemingly every day. No one paying attention can doubt that our political process has been eviscerated by the undue influence of money on politics.

Another reason to attack concentrated wealth is the way in which these vast fortunes completely distort values. In NYC, new buildings with $100 million condos for people who rarely use them are built on land that might otherwise be used to build housing for lower and middle income people. Corporations use tax deductions to buy up most of the seats at sporting events so that court-side seats at a Knicks game that cost 6 dollars when I was boy now cost up to $5000. It is not hard to find other examples.

Thomas Piketty's book makes clear that the over concentration of wealth we have already experienced is likely to worsen dramatically in coming years. Our job is to devise a way to reverse this trend. Politics as usual will not suffice. We must begin to organize.
